definition: F or f is the sixth letter of the English alphabet
In music, F is the fourth note in the scale of C major
A fable is a story that teaches some moral about life.  It frequently has animals as characters.
example: ...a fable about greed

senses.definition: ' The fabric of a society is the system of ideas and views which the people of the community share and which holds them together.
example: ...three metres of fabric. [j33] ...fabric cushion covers
...a threat to the fabric of civilization

...a threat to the fabric of civilization

definition: If you fabricate a story, an explanation or a report, you invent it. What you say is not true.
example: It turned out that he'd fabricated the whole story in order to gain sympathy

definition: In informal lan~ guage, when you say that something is fabulous, you mean that you think it is wonderful.
example: You've found a job?  Fabulous! [j33] We had a fabulous time. [j33] She's a fabulous teacher

senses.definition: ' If you put up a facade, you behave in a particular way in order to deceive people about what you are really like or how you are really feeling.
example: ...the historic facade of the town hall
When I lost my job, I put on a facade of cheerfulness so that my family wouldn't see how desperate I was. [j33] Behind that cynical facade he's a lonely man

senses.definition: 2' to someone's face'  If you say something to [chsomeone's face, you say it directly to them.
example: He'd been punched in the face
...a clock face. [j33] They were perched on a sheer cliff face. [j33] He climbed the eastern face of the mountain
How could anyone build a house in the Australian tropics with all the windows facing north? [j33] I'd prefer to sit facing the door
Greg finally faced his boss to ask whether he would be retrenched. [j33] I can't face Rolf any more[j4]I feel so bad about not helping him
Poor Laurella was trying to put on a brave face when she was wheeled off to the operating theatre
Michaela won't say to my face that I work too slowly, but she goes round the office telling everyone else

definition: Someone you describe as faceless is a member of an organisation or government agency who makes decisions which affect people but who remains anonymous.
example: One of those faceless bureaucrats decided to cut my benefits

senses.definition: ' You also use facelift to describe improving the appearance of a place such as a building or an area of ground.
example: This can make your face look thinner and makes your wrinkles disappear
I see your offices have had a facelift. [j33] We've decided to give the kitchen a facelift with a new coat of paint

senses.definition: ' You also use facelift to describe improving the appearance of a place such as a building or an area of ground.

senses.definition: ' A facet is one of the aspects or parts of something such as an organisation, structure, idea or plan.
example: You need to understand the various facets of the company before you start working here
' A facet is one of the small, polished surfaces of a precious stone

definition: In formal language, you say you facilitate something when you make it possible or easier.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun facilitation'
example: An additional lane on the highway should facilitate access to the northern suburbs. [j33] This seminar aims to facilitate the participation of women in ethnic organisations

senses.definition: ' Facility is also the ease with which you can do something that needs a certain skill.
example: The resort has a wide range of facilities, from tennis courts to fully equipped offices. [j33] This photocopier has a facility to enlarge or reduce the image
Sandy's facility in expressing herself is amazing in a three-year-old
' facilities' When you refer to the facilities of a building, you mean the toilet and bathroom.  A similar word is amenities

definition: A facsimile is an exact copy of something such as a book or other written text.
example: The latest book on Henry Lawson's poetry includes facsimiles of his early manuscripts

senses.definition: ' in fact or in actual fact'  If you say in fact, or in actual fact, you want to stress what you are saying, or extend what you have already said.
example: Just give me the facts, not what you think about it. [j33] The report gives many interesting facts and statistics
The situation here has become pro~ gressively worse[j4]you can't deny the fact
Obesity can kill.  As a matter of fact, it is one of today's most serious health problems. [j33] 'I don't suppose you've finished yet?'  'As a matter of fact, I have
I don't like her much, in fact I really loathe her. [j33] He looks quite old, but in fact he's only fifty. [j33] In actual fact, I've already been waiting for an hour
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective See factual'.

definition: A faction is a group within an organisation or party who share the same ideas and aims.  Their ideas may not be the same as those of other members of the organisation.
example: Conflict between left and right factions has been a consistent theme in the party's history

senses.definition: ' In mathematics, a factor is a number which is multiplied by another factor to give the product.
example: Smoking is a major factor in heart disease. [j33] I left because of several factors, but poor pay was the main one. [j33] Time, cost and quality are the factors we have to consider
The numbers 3 and 5 are factors of 15. [j33] Costs have increased by a factor of ten

senses.definition: ' factory floor'  The factory floor is the area in a factory where you find the machines and the people who work with them.  This area is distinct from the offices.
example: He works in a car factory
Carol was promoted from the factory floor to a sales position

definition: Something is factual if it refers to events, situations or things that really exist.  Factual writing does not include anything about feelings or imagination.
example: Please give a strictly factual account. [j33] The report contained several factual errors

senses.definition: ' Your faculties are your mental powers.  They are your ability to do things such as think, speak, reason and remember.
example: ...the Arts Faculty. [j33] ...the Faculty of Engineering. [j33] ...a meeting for all members of the faculty
Robert's faculties were so seriously affected by the accident that he had to re- learn everything, even speaking

senses.definition: a' If something fades, it becomes weaker or disappears.
example: The curtains on the western side of the house have faded badly
The sound of the engine faded into the distance. [j33] His strength was beginning to fade. [j33] Her anger faded in the face of his distress

' fade in or fade out'  This is a technical phrase used in sound and film recording. When sound or picture fades in, the sound slowly becomes louder and the picture becomes brighter. When sound and image fade out, they gradually disappear

definition: ' Fahrenheit is an older scale for measuring temperature which is still used in some countries
note: ... COMPARE this with Celsius, which is the modern scale for measuring temperature.  [j32] ... NOTE In written language, you will probably see a ;dg, but in spoken language we say 'degree'.
example: In this scale, the melting point of ice is 32 degrees above zero (32;dgF), and the boiling point of water is 212 degrees above zero (212;dgF)

senses.definition: ' If a machine or a piece of equipment fails, it doesn't work properly or it stops working altogether.
example: Some people have still failed to return their forms. [j33] That's the second appointment she's failed to keep
Kris has failed her maths test
The brakes suddenly failed and I couldn't stop the car. [j33] If the power fails, the emergency electricity is generated
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun See failure'.[j35]'adjective failed' ...a failed attempt.  ...a failed actor.

senses.definition: ' A failing is a part of someone's character or of a plan that is not as good as the rest of it or as it ought to be.
example: You're too impatient, that's your main failing. [j33] A serious failing in the report was its lack of detail about costs. 2 ' '[cf2]preposition If you are going to do something failing something else, you plan on doing it if[fj the other thing doesn't happen.  [cf2]First we'll try[fj the existing bore.  Failing that, we'll have to cart[fj water into the settlement. [j33] Ask Sue or, failing her, Tony

senses.definition: ' If there is a failure in something such as a piece of equipment, it isn't working properly or it stops working.
example: The operation was a failure[j4]Jim's sight has not improved
We'd better stock up on candles[j4]I bet we'll have at least one power failure this winter

senses.definition: ' If you faint, you start feeling dizzy and may even lose consciousness.
example: He fainted from the shock. 2 ' '[cf2]adjective If something is faint, it is not strong or intense.  [cf2]You can only see a faint outline of the building through the haze. [j33] The echo here is rather faint. [j33] She gave a faint smile

senses.definition: ' fair go'  In informal language, a fair go is a chance or opportunity to do something or get something.
example: Kylie's hair has become much fairer over the holidays
Mario's examination results were fair[j4]nothing special, I'm afraid
As a teacher, you must be fair to every student. [j33] Do you think that a one-year sentence for drink-driving is fair? [j33] I'm only asking for a fair hearing
The state-of-origin match this year was one of the fairest matches I've seen for a while[j4]hardly any kicking or hitting at all
It's been fair all day so far. [j33] Let's hope tomorrow will be fair
Let's go to the street fair
Paul is fair game for all the school bullies because he never hits back

People in small business need to be given a fair go. '  '[cf2] You often say fair go when you want to be given a chance or when you think you are being treated unfairly.  [cf2]'Finished the cleaning up yet?'  'Fair go, mate!  I've only got one pair of hands
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb See fairly'.[j35]'noun fairness' In all fairness, I can't blame him for being angry.  ...treat all students with fairness.

example: The Australian states federated in 1901

senses.definition: ' mixed feelings'  If you have mixed feelings about something, you are not sure what to think of it. In some ways it's good and in other ways it's bad.
example: I had a sudden feeling that there was someone in the room
Sometimes you have to follow your feelings, and not logic. [j33] I experienced a great feeling of sadness when he left
The general feeling amongst us is that we should accept the offer

We need someone more feeling in the role of liaison officer.  5 ' gut feeling'  '[cf2] In informal language, a gut feeling is an idea or thought which you have very strongly but can't explain.  [cf2]I've just got this gut feeling that he's not being straight with us. [j33] My gut feeling is that we should go ahead
I've got mixed feelings about moving[j4]the job itself is perfect, but it means leaving my family and friends

senses.definition: ' If something is fierce, it is very strong or intense.
example: The headmaster can be fierce, but he's very kind. [j33] She gave me a fierce look. [j33] There was a fierce dog chained up outside. [j33] He made a fierce attack on the prime minister
A fierce storm raged outside. [j33] There was fierce competition for the funding. [j33] He felt a fierce love for her. [j33] The heat in January can be really fierce
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb fiercely' She was fiercely protective of him.

senses.definition: 1' fight off'  If you fight off someone or something, you resist them and try to make them run away or disappear.
example: Seth was punished for fighting with other boys. [j33] She fought her attackers and drove them off. [j33] The documentary showed two male kangaroos fighting. [j33] I once saw Mohammed Ali fight
There were protests against our soldier fighting in Vietnam. [j33] My father fought the Japanese in the Second World War

They fought over the division of the profits. [j33] Anna's always fighting with her sister[j4]I can't stand the noise. [j33] I've been fighting with the council over the planning consent. 4 ' '[cf2]verb When two sporting teams fight, they both try to win a match or game.  [cf2]Casuarina is fighting Palmerston in next Saturday's match
Our aim is to fight discrimination in every form. [j33] She's been fighting cancer for several months
Doctors seem to be fighting a losing battle against the spread of AIDS. [j33] I tried to persuade her, but I was fighting a losing battle

I'm not accepting my dismissal just like that[j4]I'm going to fight back in the courts. [j33] She was determined to fight back against her illness. '  '[cf2] If you fight back an emotion, you try not to feel it or at least not to express it. [cf2]I had to fight back my anger when the neighbour's dog dug up my garden. [j33] He fought back tears as he described his father's death

We must continue to fight for minority rights. [j33] I had to fight for my education, so I know how important it is. 9 ' fighting chance'  '[cf2] If you have a fighting chance, you have a reasonable prospect of success although you'll still have to work very hard.  [cf2]With the leader out of the race, we're in with a fighting chance. [j33] My teachers reckon I've got a fighting chance of getting a place at college
'How are you today?'  'Fighting fit and ready to go.' [j33] Steve was soon fighting fit again after the operation
I managed to fight off the mugger. [j33] I've been trying to fight off a cold with lots of vitamin C
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun fight' [j35]'noun fighter'

senses.definition: ' A fine is money that someone has to pay because they have broken a rule or law.
example: This cabinet is a very fine piece of work. [j33] I am in fine health. [j33] This is a fine example of what I mean
Tasha's fine, but I can't stand her brother. [j33] If you want to stay here, that's fine, but you must let me know
'How are you doing?'  'I'm fine, thanks.' [j33] 'How are you going?'  'Fine, and you?' [j33] 'How are your parents?'  'They're fine
We've had three fine days this week
This shampoo is suitable for fine hair. [j33] The dinner service is made of fine bone china. [j33] The spider weaves a fine web

I ran my hand through the fine white sand.  7 ' '[cf2]adjective If something is fine, it is difficult to see, recognise or understand.  [cf2]There's a fine line between assertiveness and arrogance. [j33] Philosophers love to make fine distinctions between concepts
The judge set the fine at $500. [j33] His driver's licence was cancelled because of unpaid parking fines
' fine arts'  The fine arts are the visual arts such as painting, drawing and sculpture
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb fine' That suits me fine.  I'm managing fine now.  Fine, I'll pick you up at six.[j35]'adverb finely' The silver box is very finely worked.  Chop the vegetables finely.

senses.definition: ' slip through someone's fingers'  If something slips through someone's fingers, they miss out on a good opportunity that they had.
senses.rest: Y@u:'ll nEvEr ha:vE a: cha:ncE li:kE tha:t a:ga:i:n[j4]why di:d y@u: lEt i:t sli:p thr@u:gh y@u:r fi:ngErs?

' The fingers of the glove are the parts that are shaped to cover the fingers of your hand

A finger of land sticks out into the sea. [j33] Cut the pastry into fingers. [j33] I bought a packet of chocolate fingers. [j33] We had fish fingers for lunch. 4 ' '[cf2]verb If you finger something, you touch it with your hands and make it dirty.  [cf2]Don't finger the biscuits and put them back on the plate! [j33] The book jacket had been badly fingered
' finger food' Finger food is food that you can eat without using cutlery, such as small sandwiches or nuts.  It is generally served at parties and receptions where people eat standing up

senses.definition: ' If someone is finicky, they are fussy and demanding. They want every detail of something to be correct even though it's not necessary.
example: Embroidery is too finicky for me[j4]I'd rather do woodwork. [j33] The model plane kit was full of finicky little pieces
Maryanne is so finicky[j4]she gets upset if the blue pen's where the red one's supposed to be. [j33] Both my kids are finicky eaters

senses.definition: ' finish up'  If you finish up somewhere or in a certain situation, you get there after going to various places or having various experiences.
example: I'll stop when I've finished this page. [j33] He finished his education at the age of fourteen. [j33] Have you finished complain~ ing? [j33] What time does your class finish?  2 ' '[cf2]verb When you finish food or drink, you consume all of it. [cf2]Come on, kids, finish your dinner

That race has finished me for the day[j4]there's no way I can run in the relay. [j33] Paying for both my daughters' weddings within six months just about finished me. 4 ' '[cf2]noun The finish is the end or last part of something, especially a race or match.  [cf2]I want to see this project through to the finish. [j33] The Melbourne Cup saw a dramatic finish this year. [j33] There was a really close finish in the final

The gold finish was beginning to rub off.  b ' '[cf2]noun A finish is also the texture or appearance of a surface.  [cf2]Polish it to obtain a smooth finish. [j33] I like the matt finish on these photographs
' finish off'  In informal lan~ guage, if you say you finish off a wounded animal or person, you mean you kill them, sometimes to put them out of pain
'Where did you finish up last night?' 'A small wine bar in the city.' [j33] I never thought I'd finish up in Australia. [j33] Get an education[j4]you don't want to finish up like me
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective See fiery'.

definition: If something is finite, it has a limit.
example: The number of possibilities is very large, but finite. [j33] I'm warning you, my patience is finite

senses.definition: 6' set fire to'  If you set fire to something, you make it begin burning.

definition: Firearms are guns that a person can carry, such as revolvers or rifles
A firebreak is a wide path through bush or forest where all the trees and shrubs have been cleared to prevent fire from spreading
A firefighter is someone whose job it is to put out fires in buildings or the bush

senses.definition: ' A fireplace is a place in a room where you can burn coal to provide warmth.
example: They've got a wonderful old fireplace in the living room
' A fireplace is a structure in the open air, for example at a camp site, where you can light a fire for cooking

senses.definition: ' first name'  Your first name is the name that distinguishes you from other members of your family and other people with the same surname. In Australian society most people put this before their surname.  Another term for it is given name. 10 ' first things first'  '
example: The first player to finish wins. [j33] Amy is the first girl on the left. [j33] Tom won first prize. [j33] I was very nervous the first time. [j33] The first thing to remember is not to panic
Leo has always put his family first[j4]even when work pressures have been quite demanding
Which came first, the chicken or the egg? [j33] First I collected the data and then I analysed it. [j33] I'll be with you in a minute[j4]let me finish this first. [j33] First, let me apologise
Who arrived first? [j33] Newton first described the laws of gravity
We first met at university and we've been friends ever since. [j33] When did you first feel this pain? [j33] When we first came to Australia, everything was strange, but I soon settled in
Don't be discouraged if you don't succeed at first. [j33] At first I couldn't understand a word, but it gradually became clear
I'm doing a course in first aid. [j33] We keep a first aid kit in the bathroom cabinet
We must ensure that our standards are first class at all times

If you say first things first, you mean that the most important thing needs to be done before everything else.  [cf2]No, Mario, you can't have your pocket money now.  First things first: clean up your room, put the garbage out, then you can have your $5
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb firstly' Firstly I don't want to, and secondly I haven't got time.

She fished in her handbag for her keys. [j33] He fished a $50 note from his pocket

comment: verb forms fits, fitted, fitting; '[cf2]adjective forms fitter, fittest

senses.definition: 1' fits and starts'  If something happens in fits and starts, it begins and stops again in a jerky, uncontrolled way instead of as a steady, continuous process.
example: These jeans don't fit very well. [j33] The large size should fit Geoffrey. [j33] The lounge wouldn't fit through the door
His background fits well with the job requirements. [j33] None of these courses quite fits my needs
I can't fit anything more into my suitcase

Fit the hose to this nozzle. [j33] I'm thinking of having airconditioning fitted in my car. [j33] I called a plumber to fit the new taps. 5 ' '[cf2]adjective If you are fit, you are physically strong and healthy and can take exercise without becoming tired quickly.  [cf2]I've never felt so fit since I took up swimming each day
The house isn't fit for visitors[j4]I'll have to tidy up first.  [j33] He's not fit to look after children. [j33] This is not a fit use of public funds
He's an epileptic, but his fits are controlled by drugs
The fit of the dress round the thighs isn't quite right. [j33] Trim away any surplus to get a good fit. [j33] It'll just about go in, but it's a tight fit

I try to fit in a run at least twice a week. [j33] The doctor can fit you in at 11.30. '[cf2] If you fit in, you conform with other people.  [cf2]Somehow I felt I'd never fit in with the other students. [j33] I'm willing to fit in with whatever suits you
That agricultural pipe fits the bill exactly[j4]it will be perfect to drain the heavy clay section of our garden

The car made its way along the road in fits and starts. [j33] It's no good studying in fits and starts[j4]you need a regular timetable. 12 ' have a fit'  '[cf2] In informal language, if you say that someone has a fit, you mean that they are very angry about something that's happened.  [cf2]Mum will have a fit when she realises how much money you've wasted
note: [j34] ... WORD FAMILY 'noun See fitness'.[j35]'adjective See fitting'.

senses.definition: ' fix up'  If you fix someone up, you help them in some way or provide for them.
example: When are you going to fix that cupboard back to the wall? [j33] I'd better fix that pole with some cement or else it may come crashing down

Fix your eyes on the top line and read the letters. [j33] I fixed my attention on her hand movements. [j33] You have to fix your mind on what you want to achieve. 3 ' '[cf2]verb If you fix something, you decide on it or settle it.  [cf2]Let's fix a date for the next meeting now. [j33] We still haven't fixed who's going to do the catering. [j33] We can't fix the price until we've got a better idea of the costs
I'll get my assistant to fix accommodation for you. [j33] My cousin fixed it for us to sit in the front row
I called in a mechanic to fix the leaking washing machine
Nadja's in a real fix[j4]she needs to visit her sister in hospital and there's no-one to look after the baby
I can't start work until I've had my morning fix of coffee
Luigi has a fixed idea that we all hate him. [j33] The loan carries a fixed interest rate. [j33] For a fixed price of $25 you can have any two courses

senses.definition: ' If a liquid fizzes, it contains a lot of tiny bubbles of gas.
example: I shook the can of lemonade to make it fizz more

definition: A fizzer is something that begins well but fails miserably soon afterwards.
example: Ron's beach party was a real fizzer[j4]the rain came pouring down an hour after it started

senses.definition: ' fizzle out'  If something fizzles out, it is abandoned because people have lost enthusiasm or interest.
example: The gas fizzled from the broken pipe

senses.definition: ' If you flat with someone, you share a rented flat with them.  Usually you are all young, single people.
example: The country was flat as far as the eye could see
When I had a slipped disk I was flat on my back for two weeks. [j33] Lay the paintings down flat on the floor
Open the map out flat so that we can see the whole thing
With so few people there, the party was rather flat. [j33] After all the excitement of the election, the next few days were rather flat. [j33] January is always a flat month for news
' If something such as champagne is flat, the gas in it has escaped and it has lost its taste
' A battery is flat when all the power in it has been used up
' A tyre is flat when the air in it has escaped through a puncture
' A flat is a set of rooms for people to live in.  Usually they are in large buildings which are divided into several flats.  Other words for this are apartment, home unit and unit
I flat with three other students. [j33] Lara and I are going to flat together next year. [j33] I'm sick of flatting[j4]I want a place of my own
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb See flatten'.

senses.definition: ' follow up' If you follow something up, you continue to be involved with it or you continue some work that has been done previously.
example: The dinner was followed by dancing. [j33] The chorus follows each of these verses. [j33] I left at that point, so I don't know what followed
You go ahead since you know the way, and we'll follow you. [j33] He suspected that he was being followed. [j33] A long line of cars followed the hearse
Follow this road for about a kilometre, then turn left
I was too tired to follow the lecture. [j33] I didn't understand every word in the Italian movie, but enough to follow the plot

senses.definition: ' food for thought' If you say something is food for thought, you mean that it causes you to think carefully about something.  It may make you change your ideas.

senses.definition: ' make a fool of' If someone makes a fool of you, they make you seem to be silly or stupid.  You can also make a fool of yourself if you do something silly or stupid.
example: Kay's a complete fool! How can she spend three hundred dollars on a dress when she hasn't paid the water bill? [j33] I felt such a fool when I realised I'd gone to the wrong address. 2 ' '[cf2]verb If someone fools you, they trick you into believing something which isn't true, usually as a joke.  [cf2]His disguise fooled us all. [j33] For a while she had me fooled[j4]I really believed she was going to leave
The lecturer made a fool of Howard in public[j4] I'm not going to his lectures again. [j33] I made a complete fool of myself by putting salt in my coffee
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun See folly'.[j35]'adjective foolish' He made a foolish mistake.  It would be foolish to ignore the opportunity.[j35]'adverb foolishly'

definition: If something is foolproof, it isn't easy to damage it or use it the wrong way, even if you don't really know what you're doing.

senses.definition: ' stand on your own feet' If you stand on your own feet, you are independent and don't rely on other people.  You can emphasise this by saying stand on your own two feet.
example: Our house is at the foot of a hill. [j33] I added my name to the foot of the list. [j33] The blankets have slipped off the foot of the bed
He's nearly six feet tall
Who's going to foot the bill for this extravaganza?  The taxpayer as usual!  [j33] Col will have to foot the bill for his son's car accident
We've done very well so far, but we must keep our feet on the ground
I've been indulgent so far, but this time I'm putting my foot down
Susanna, you really have to grow up and learn to stand on your own two feet

definition: A footnote is an addition to a piece of writing which gives extra information. It is not included in the main body of the text but appears at the bottom of the page or at the end of the chapter or book.
example: Footnote 7 gives the source for these figures

definition: A footpath is a path, especially one that is at the side of a road or street, for pedestrians only
A footprint is a mark that a foot or shoe leaves in a soft surface such as sand or mud.
example: We could tell where the children had run by following their footprints

definition: Footsteps are the sounds that you make with your feet when you walk.
example: We heard the gate creak and then the footsteps of someone approaching the door

definition: Footwear is what you wear on your feet, such as shoes, boots, sandals and slippers.

definition: If you forage for supplies, you go and search for them.
example: In traditional Aboriginal society, much of the day was spent foraging for food. [j33] I foraged in the stationery cupboard for a suitable envelope

definition: In fairly formal language, forbearance is patience and tolerance when people are behaving badly.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective forbearing'
example: He showed great forbearance in allowing the children to roam the house and make a mess

comment: verb forms forbids, forbade or forbad, forbidden or '[cf2]  forbid, forbidding
definition: If you forbid someone to do something, you don't allow them to do it.  You tell them that they must not do it.
example: The boss has forbidden us to mention the project to anyone outside the company. [j33] Smoking indoors is strictly forbidden

definition: If someone or something is forbidding, they seem difficult to deal with.
example: We faced a long climb up a forbidding slope. [j33] Her manner is forbidding, but she's really very kind

senses.definition: 2' in force' If people attend an event in force, a great number of them go to it.
example: The robber forced the manager to open the safe. [j33] I can't force my son to study[j4] he has to find his own motivation. [j33] The new law will force companies to keep better records
I forced a knife into the crack. [j33] He forced his way past the security guards
Hino forced the lock with a screwdriver. [j33] The window tends to stick[j4]you have to force it a bit. [j33] If the drawer is jammed, don't force it
The car crashed into the house with such force that the wall collapsed. [j33] The force of the explosion was felt several kilometres away
He had the protesters removed by force
It was his point about costs that carried most force. [j33] The new regulations were not properly thought through and lack force
...magnetic forces. [j33] ...the force of gravity

senses.definition: ' If someone is forceful, they are energetic and assertive.
example: You need to be a bit more forceful in claiming your due. [j33] His forceful personality saw the project to a successful conclusion. 2 ' '[cf2]adjective If something such as an argument or an example is described as forceful, it is effective or convincing.  [cf2]What happened last night is a forceful argument for stricter gun control
note: ... DO NOT CONFUSE this word with forcible.  [j32] ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb forcefully'

definition: Forceps are an instrument that is used by doctors to hold things
note: ... NOTE that this word is used in the plural form.

definition: If something is described as forcible, it involves the use of physical strength or even violence.
note: ... DO NOT CONFUSE this word with forceful.  [j32] ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb forcibly'
example: The broken window was a sign that the burglars had made forcible entry

definition: A ford is a shallow part of a river where people or vehicles can cross

senses.definition: ' The fore parts of something are its front parts, in contrast to the rear or '
example: hind parts.  [cf2]The fore limbs of the kangaroo are quite small. 2 ' to the fore' '[cf2] If someone or something comes to the fore, they appear at the front or in the best position or they become more popular than the others
note: ... DO NOT CONFUSE this with for or four.

definition: Your forearm is the part of your arm between your elbow and your wrist
Your forebears are members of your family or cultural group who lived a long time ago
example: This word is usually used in the plural

definition: A forecast is a statement about something that is likely to happen in the future.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb forecast' He forecast that interest rates would rise.
example: Did you listen to the weather forecast on the radio this morning? [j33] The economic forecast for next year is gloomy

definition: Your forefinger is the finger on each hand that is next to the thumb
note: ... ANOTHER TERM for this is index finger.

senses.definition: ' If you say that someone or something is in the foreground, you mean that they are noticeable or receive attention.
example: Peta is forever trying to push herself into the foreground[j4]the manager hardly notices the other staff any more. [j33] Economic measures are likely to be in the foreground next month
note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is background.

definition: Your forehead is the part of your face above your eyes and below your hair
example: See the picture at body

senses.definition: ' In formal language, if you say something is foreign to you, you mean that it seems strange and unusual.
example: You shouldn't buy foreign products[j4]buy Australian. [j33] Foreign tourists often expect a very high standard of service
The body's immune system will often reject foreign tissue. [j33] A foreign substance was detected in the sample
The idea was quite foreign to me[j4]I would never have thought of it myself
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun foreigner' As a foreigner, Maria felt isolated at college.

example: Meeting the deadline should be foremost in our minds. [j33] The foremost problem is how to maintain quality

definition: Forensic means relat~ ing to scientific tests that are carried out in order to solve a crime.
example: ...forensic medicine. [j33] ...a forensic laboratory

definition: If you foresee some~ thing happening, you know or assume that it is going to happen.
example: I can foresee several difficulties with this plan. [j33] Paulo should have foreseen that he'd need to borrow more money. [j33] She claimed to have foreseen the disaster in a dream

definition: In rather formal language, if you say something foreshadows an event, you mean that it indicates that the event is likely to happen.
example: The ground had rumbled for days, foreshadowing an eruption of the volcano. [j33] These disagreements foreshadowed more serious disputes to come

...pine forest

definition: A foreword is an introduction to a book which recommends it or states why it has been written
note: ... DO NOT CONFUSE this with preface, which is an introduction by the author.  The normal order is for the foreword to come before the preface.
example: It is usually by someone other than the author of the book, often someone famous

definition: If you forfeit something, you lose your right to own it.
example: Items on lay-by are forfeited if not paid for and collected within two months

senses.definition: ' If you forge something such as a friendship or a rela~ tionship, you put effort into forming it because you want it to last.

definition: Your forte is something that you do or know very well.  It is a particular strength of yours.

senses.definition: ' look forward to' If you look forward to something, you eagerly wait for it to happen. You expect that you will enjoy it very much.
example: The car jerked forward and then came to a halt on the grass
The project was in question for a while, but it's moving forward again now. [j33] I feel I'm really going forward with my studies this year
We need to look forward and forget about past mistakes and problems
Can we move the pottery class forward by an hour? [j33] The launch has been brought forward to next month

adjective If someone is forward, they are open, direct and bold in dealing with other people.  [cf2]Being forward can sometimes scare other people off. [j33] I nearly volunteered, but I didn't want to appear too forward. [j33] You need to be pretty forward if you want to get noticed
Would you mind forwarding my mail to me while I'm away? [j33] I signed the invoice and forwarded it to the accounts department. [j33] We will forward the item on receipt of your payment
He travels backwards and forwards between Tokyo and Sydney
I'm really looking forward to the Christmas break. [j33] I look forward to meeting you again
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective forwarding' ...a forward~ ing address.

definition: Fright is sudden, strong fear.

definition: If something frightens you, it makes you suddenly feel afraid or anxious.

senses.definition: ' In informal language, you can use frightful to emphasise how bad something is.

definition: (<weak form>  'times,0'[cp8.5]fr[j17]m') From is used to indicate a starting point of some kind. You use it to say that something is distant from something else, either in time or place, or in some other way.  You can also use it to refer to an origin or a cause.

senses.definition: ' up front' If you pay for something up front, you pay for it in advance, before you receive it.
example: We walked to the front of the building. [j33] Our house is on the river front. [j33] ...a shop front
' A battle front is the part of an army which is closest to the enemy
' If something acts as a front for an activity, it is a cover for something that is probably illegal or secret
' A front is also a group of people, or a movement, which wants to achieve a political aim
' in front of' Anything that is in front of an object is placed before it, especially if it is between you and the object as you look at it
' front up' If you front up, you arrive or turn up  somewhere
If the car costs $30 000, I'll pay $5000 up front and the rest when it's delivered
